abstract.p: Jewish Family Service retired executive director Sandra King's letter on Jonathan Kozol's Aug 22 Op-Ed article on his father's deterioriation from Alzheimer's; says help must be available for both young and old--for families of all ages whose resources are not sufficient to meet their needs

block.p: Re ''Losing My Father, One Day at a Time'' (Op-Ed, Aug. 22), Jonathan Kozol's touching description of the impact of Alzheimer's disease on its aged victims and their families:

By sharing his personal experience, Mr. Kozol dramatically reminds us that help must be available for both the young and the old -- for families of all ages whose resources are not sufficient to meet their needs.
Re ''Losing My Father, One Day at a Time'' (Op-Ed, Aug. 22), Jonathan Kozol's touching description of the impact of Alzheimer's disease on its aged victims and their families:

By sharing his personal experience, Mr. Kozol dramatically reminds us that help must be available for both the young and the old -- for families of all ages whose resources are not sufficient to meet their needs.

Too often, politicians and policy makers suggest that one age group must suffer if money is to be provided to serve the needs of the other. As a civilized and truly compassionate society, we cannot neglect either the young or the old or focus on one at the expense of the other.
The writer retired as executive director of the Jewish Family Service of Los Angeles.
